Americans seem to be more eager to cooperate with Germany than the Germans are with the U.S., with 69% of Americans wanting more cooperation with Germany, compared to just 50% of Germans who say the same about the U.S. [7]. This is even though the percentage of Germans who want to cooperate more with the U.S. has risen since 2018, when 47% wanted less cooperation with America [7]. Interestingly, when it comes to choosing between closer ties with the U.S. or Russia, Germans are more divided than Americans, with 39% preferring the U.S. and 25% preferring Russia, while 30% suggest both [4].  ![The image is a chart comparing political party alignment with some numerical percentages in the U.S. and Germany.](image4) In the U.S., this difference in opinion towards closer relations with certain countries seems to be influenced by political affiliation. Republicans, for example, are more likely to prioritize Israel as a foreign policy partner (26%) compared to Democrats (9%) [10]. This is evident in how both Democrats and Republicans agree that the UK is their most important partner, but Republicans are more enthusiastic about Israel [8].  ![The image is a comparative chart showing the opinions of Americans and Germans towards the United Nations (UN), European Union (EU), and Russia.](image5) In terms of defense spending, there is a notable partisan divide in the U.S., with more Republicans favoring increased defense spending in Europe compared to Democrats [5]. ![The image is a line graph showing trends over three years, from 2017 to 2019, for two political affiliations: "Republican/Lean Rep" and "Democrat/Lean Dem." ](image1) However, this difference has been narrowing, with a 14 percentage point decrease among Republicans who believe European allies should increase their defense budgets between 2017 and 2019, and a smaller decline among Democrats during the same period [5]. ![The image contains two bar charts comparing the preferences of Republican/Lean Republican and Democrat/Lean Democrat respondents towards certain countries.](image3) 

The titles of the charts in which the results are grouped by political affiliation are: "image1", "image3", "image4", and "image5".

Americans are divided about whether they see Islam as more likely than other religions to encourage violence among its believers:  46% say it is more likely, while 45% say it is not more likely [4]. The share of the public saying that Islam is more likely than other religions to encourage violence has dropped four percentage points since a historical high of 50% in September 2014 [4].  ![The image is a line graph comparing two perceptions over time (from 2002 to 2015) regarding the encouragement of violence among followers of a religion versus other religions.](image4) For much of the past decade, public views on this measure have been closely divided [4]. However, this masks a significant and growing partisan divide [7]. The partisan divide over whether Islam encourages violence is now as wide as it has ever been [8]. Fully 68% of Republicans say Islam encourages violence more than other religions, a historical high but little changed since last fall [8].  ![The image is a line graph depicting trends in percentages over time, from 2002 to 2015, for three groups: Republicans, Democrats, and Independents.](image5) By contrast, just 30% of Democrats say Islam is more likely to encourage violence than other religions, down from 42% in September 2014 [8]. In contrast, the share of Democrats associating Islam with violence has declined 12 percentage points since last year, from 42% to 30% [6].  The share of liberals saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence is down 14-points since the fall of 2014 [3]. Perceptions of whether Islam encourages violence more than other religions have remained relatively stable overall, but there is a growing partisan divide, with Republicans becoming more likely and Democrats less likely to view Islam as encouraging violence.

Interestingly, familiarity seems to breed acceptance, with those most aware of the concept finding it much more realistic  [6].  However, the sentiment leans more toward worry (72%) than enthusiasm (33%) regarding robots and computers taking over human jobs [9]. ![The image is a horizontal bar chart representing levels of enthusiasm and worry. The public is divided on whether there should be limitations on the extent to which businesses can automate jobs [7]. While 58% believe there should be limits on replacing human jobs with machines, 41% think businesses are justified in doing so if it results in better work at lower costs ![Opinions on whether businesses are justified in replacing human workers with machines based on efficiency and cost](image2). This apprehension may stem from concerns about job displacement, as illustrated by the significant proportion of people who believe certain professions, such as fast food workers (77%) and insurance claim processors (65%), are likely to be affected by automation ![Likelihood of different jobs or professions being affected by automation](image3). However, there is strong support (85%) for the idea that machines should primarily handle jobs that pose dangers or health risks to humans [9], reflecting a desire to prioritize worker safety. ![Public opinion on policies related to automation, including limiting machines to dangerous jobs, guaranteed income, and national service programs](image4) This suggests that the public is more open to machine involvement in the workforce when it addresses hazardous conditions and complements, rather than replaces, human labor.  In conclusion, public opinion on limiting machine use in the workforce is mixed, with a preference for machines taking over dangerous jobs and support for policies protecting workers' well-being.

Most Americans generally view K-12 public school education as average [6], with 25% believing it to be the best in the world or above average, 43% considering it average, and 30% deeming it below average. ![The image is a horizontal bar chart comparing the perceptions of U.S. adults regarding the quality of different levels of education in the U.S.](image5) However, this view shifts considerably when looking specifically at those with postgraduate degrees in STEM fields. In conclusion, while general opinion is mixed, STEM postgraduate degree holders are significantly more likely to view K-12 public school education as below average.

The median investment trends in Europe and the U.S. show some similarities but also notable differences across various funding stages from 2004 to 2009. In the U.S., all investment stages, including Seed, First, Second, and Later, experienced a peak around 2006-2007 followed by a decline by 2009. ![The image is a line graph showing the trend of median U.S. investments from 2004 to 2009, differentiated by investment stages.](image2)  However, the European market exhibited a slightly different pattern.  ![The image is a line graph showing median European investments from 2004 to 2009.](image5) Notably,  "Later" stage investments in Europe peaked around 2007-2008, while other stages remained relatively stable. This difference could potentially be attributed to the European venture capital landscape being characterized as a "cottage industry" [9] with limited participation from major investors like pension and endowment funds, which represent a significant portion of the US VC industry. This structural difference might explain the less pronounced peaks and valleys in European median investments compared to the US.  In conclusion, from 2004 to 2009, US investments peaked mid-period and then declined, while European investments showed less pronounced trends with later-stage investments peaking towards 2007-2008.

The authors of the climate and health assessment use two types of language to communicate uncertainty in the report: confidence and likelihood [9]. Confidence in a finding is determined by the type, amount, quality, strength, and consistency of the evidence, as well as the degree of expert agreement [9].  ![This chart displays the different levels of confidence and what they mean](image2).  Likelihood, on the other hand, describes the probability of an impact occurring [7].  ![This chart depicts the numerical ranges associated with probability terms](image3). When there is sufficient scientific justification, Key Findings also include a likelihood designation, which is determined by expert assessment and consensus of the chapter author teams [5]. These teams evaluate the available literature, the quality and quantity of the evidence, and the level of agreement across different studies to determine the appropriate level of confidence or likelihood [5]. More information about this process, and how each team reached a consensus, can be found in the Traceable Account section for each chapter, Appendix 1, or Appendix 4 [5]. The assessment aims to provide stakeholders with a comprehensive, evidence-based understanding of the risks climate change poses to human health in the United States [10].  

The levels of confidence and likelihood are evaluated based on the type, amount, quality, and consistency of evidence; the degree of expert agreement; and an assessment of the available literature.

Americans' views on the ethical standards and extremism of the Republican and Democratic parties are deeply divided along partisan lines [4]. While a slim majority of both Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) believe their own party has high ethical standards, this sentiment changes drastically when evaluating the opposing party [1]. This partisan divide is further highlighted by the fact that over 80% of both Republicans and Democrats believe their own party has good policy ideas, while less than 25% say the same about the opposing party [4]. ![This image is a bar chart comparing perceptions of the Republican and Democratic parties among U.S. adults.](image2)

This trend of partisan loyalty extends to perceptions of extremism as well. Roughly three-quarters of both Republicans and Democrats view the *other* party as "too extreme," while only about 20% believe this about their own party [4]. Interestingly, independents are significantly more likely than partisans to perceive a lack of ethical standards in both parties. 34% of independents, including equal shares of Republican and Democratic leaners, believe neither party upholds high ethical standards, compared to only 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats [7].

Education level also plays a role in shaping these perceptions. Among those with at least a college degree, 31% believe that neither the Republican nor the Democratic Party upholds high ethical standards, indicating a more cynical outlook compared to those with lower education levels [3]. This difference in perception based on education and political affiliation is further illustrated when examining how different groups apply the label of "high ethical standards" to the two parties. ![The image is a bar chart with three categories:

1. **Describes both parties** 
2. **Describes one party, not the other**
3. **Describes neither party**](image4)

In conclusion, perceptions of ethics and extremism in political parties are heavily influenced by political affiliation and, to a lesser extent, education level, with partisans often viewing their own party favorably while criticizing the opposition.

Just $41\%$ of Americans believe the GOP upholds high ethical standards, nearly mirroring the $42\%$ who say the same about the Democratic Party [9]. This suggests a significant portion of the public perceives ethical shortcomings in both parties. This perception is particularly pronounced among Independents, with $34\%$ stating neither party meets high ethical standards, a much larger proportion than the $19\%$ of Republicans and $18\%$ of Democrats who hold the same view [1]. 
![This image is a bar chart comparing perceptions of the Republican and Democratic parties among U.S. adults.](image3) 
Interestingly, while majorities within both parties still view their own as ethically sound (66% Republicans, 64% Democrats), there's a notable degree of skepticism compared to other party attributes [4]. This skepticism is further amplified when considering education levels. A significant $31\%$ of those with at least a college degree believe neither party embodies high ethical standards, compared to $20\%$ among those with a high school diploma or less [5], [8]. This suggests a correlation between higher education and a more critical view of both parties' ethical practices. 
![The image is a bar chart with three categories:](image1) 
When examining perceptions of extremism, the Republican Party faces stronger criticism. $48\%$ of Americans perceive the GOP as "too extreme," surpassing the $42\%$ who hold the same view of the Democratic Party [3]. This difference in perception is even more pronounced when considering party affiliation. Roughly three-quarters of Democrats view the Republican party as "too extreme," while only two-in-ten Republicans share that sentiment about their own party [7]. This partisan divide highlights how political affiliation significantly shapes perceptions of extremism, even more so than perceptions of ethical standards. 
![The image is a bar chart comparing opinions among different political groups.](image2) 
In conclusion, while both parties face criticism regarding ethical standards, the Republican Party is viewed as more extreme, particularly among Democrats and those with higher education levels.

[2] Those with higher education levels, specifically postgraduate and four-year college degree holders, demonstrate a stronger preference for the Democratic candidate. ![This image is a bar chart showing political party preference among various demographic groups of registered voters.](image5) This preference gap narrows among voters without a college degree. [10] Independents are more likely than partisans to believe that neither party upholds high ethical standards, with a third of independents sharing this view compared to only about two-in-ten Republicans or Democrats. [1] This trend is further emphasized among those with some college experience or a high school degree or less, where 20% believe neither party demonstrates high ethical standards.  ![The image is a bar chart comparing perceptions of the Republican and Democratic parties among U.S. adults.](image2) While majorities within both the Republican (66%) and Democratic (64%) parties still view their own party as having high ethical standards [5], nearly a third of college graduates believe neither party meets this standard. [9]  ![The image is a bar chart with three categories: Describing both, one, or neither political party.](image3) This suggests a correlation between higher education levels and a more critical view of both parties' ethical standards, particularly among independents. Perceptions of ethical standards and political party preferences are intertwined with education levels and political affiliations, with higher education correlating with a greater inclination towards the Democratic party and a more critical stance on the ethical standards of both parties, especially among independents.

Public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy has seen an upward trend, rising from 46% in January 2018 to 53% in May 2018 [7].  This positive shift is also mirrored in public perception of his ability to make sound decisions regarding economic policy, as illustrated in this graph: ![This graph shows public opinion trends on handling international crises and economic policy.](image1).  A similar trend is observed in public confidence regarding Trump's handling of international crises.  This figure has climbed from 35% in January 2018 to 43% in May 2018 [10].  Interestingly, while a narrow majority still expresses little or no confidence in Trump's capacity to handle an international crisis (54%), this figure represents a decrease from April 2017 when 48% held this view [9, 10]. This shift in public opinion on both economic and international crisis management is noteworthy. However, these overall trends don't tell the whole story.  A significant partisan divide is evident when we examine these opinions. A staggering 80% of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals now express agreement with Trump on many or all issues, marking an 11 percentage point surge since the previous August [4].  This partisan divide is further highlighted when we look at specific areas like handling an international crisis, where Republican confidence in Trump has significantly grown, reaching 84% compared to 73% earlier [5].  ![This chart illustrates the partisan divide in opinions towards Trump.](image2). In contrast, the overall public opinion reveals a more mixed picture, with only 53% expressing at least some confidence in Trump's capability to make sound economic policy decisions, while 46% have little or no confidence [6]. This difference in opinion between Republicans and the general public underscores the deep partisan divide in assessing Trump's presidency.  ![This chart shows the breakdown of opinions towards Trump by political affiliation.](image3). Overall, while public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy and international crises has shown improvement, these perceptions remain deeply divided along partisan lines, with Republicans demonstrating significantly more confidence than the general public.

Public confidence in Trump’s handling of economic policy has ticked up since January ([4]).  In January, 46% of the public expressed at least some confidence in Trump’s ability to make good decisions about economic policy, which rose to 53% in May 2018 ([3]). Public confidence in Trump’s handling of international crises has followed a similar upward trajectory. ![The image shows four line graphs illustrating public opinion over time about performance in different areas](image2) This aligns with the overall observation that on some issues, public confidence in Trump has increased from earlier in the year ([7]). For instance, in January, only 35% of the public expressed confidence in Trump’s ability to handle an international crisis, rising to 43% by May 2018 ([10]).  However, despite these improvements in public confidence regarding Trump’s handling of specific issues, there is a significant disparity in sentiment between Republicans and Democrats regarding his overall conduct.  Republicans have grown significantly more confident in Trump's abilities since January ([2]). This is particularly evident in their views on his handling of an international crisis, with confidence levels rising from 73% in January to 84% ([2]).  ![This image is a bar chart comparing opinions among Republicans and Democrats in May 2018 and August 2017. It shows percentage distributions for two groups: "Among Rep/Lean Rep" and "Among Dem/Lean Dem." The numbers represent proportions for each opinion category within each time period.](image4)  In contrast, Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of Trump's conduct, with 85% expressing dislike in May 2018 ([1]). ![The image is a horizontal bar chart showing people's opinions, categorized by political affiliation.](image5) In conclusion, while public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy and international crises has risen, this positive shift is driven primarily by Republicans, as Democrats continue to hold negative views about his conduct.

Public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy has ticked up since January ([3]).  ![This image shows four line graphs illustrating public opinion over time about performance in different areas.](image3) Meanwhile, in May 2018, 43% of the public expressed confidence in Trump to handle an international crisis, up from 35% in January ([5]). Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis is generally lower than his approval rating on economic policy. ![This image shows four line graphs illustrating public opinion over time about performance in different areas.](image3)  Public confidence in Trump to handle an international crisis and the economy has generally increased since January ([6]). In conclusion, public confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis is lower than his approval rating on economic policy, but both have trended upward.

Democrats remain deeply critical of Trump's conduct, with 85% saying they don't like the way Trump conducts himself in office [5]. This stark contrast is also evident in how Republicans and Democrats perceive the ethical standards of the Trump administration. Among Democrats, there are modest differences along ideological lines, with 8% of conservative or moderate Democrats and 93% of liberal Democrats giving low marks for the ethical standards of the Trump administration [8].  ![The image is a horizontal bar chart showing people's opinions, categorized by political affiliation.](image1)  However, there is also criticism from within Trump's own party: Just 38% of Republicans say they like the way he conducts himself, while 45% say they have “mixed feelings about the way he conducts himself as president [5]. This difference in opinion is particularly noticeable along ideological lines within the Republican party, as conservative Republicans are significantly more likely than their moderate or liberal counterparts to say they like Trump’s conduct (44% to 25%, respectively) [6]. This ideological divide is further emphasized when considering the ethical standards of Trump's administration. While just 15% of conservative Republicans express negative views of the ethical standards of Trump administration officials, about a third (36%) of moderate and liberal Republicans say they are not good or poor [10]. ![The image is a bar chart comparing opinions among different political groups.](image2) Overall, the opinions of Republicans and Democrats regarding Trump's conduct and the ethical standards of his administration have remained largely unchanged, with Democrats expressing strong disapproval and Republicans showing a more mixed, ideologically divided response.

Ratings for Trump officials’ ethical standards trail past administrations [8]. ![The image is a bar chart showing approval ratings of U.S. presidents over various years.](image1) Only 39% of the public rates the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as excellent or good, while 58% rate them as not good or poor [9]. This aligns with the relatively low public approval of Trump's job performance, which has remained largely unchanged since the beginning of his presidency [2]. Public disapproval of Trump's job performance is at 42% [4], a sentiment that is likely influenced by negative perceptions of his administration's ethical standards.  In conclusion, the approval ratings of Trump administration officials' ethical standards are lower than those of past administrations, which appears to be a contributing factor to the relatively low public approval of Trump's job performance.

A Pew Research Center survey [6] revealed that 50% of voters were happy with Trump's victory, while 48% were unhappy. This reaction closely mirrored the 2012 election, where 52% were happy with Obama's win. However, both instances paled in comparison to the 2008 election, when Obama's victory garnered a 58% happiness rate [5]. This suggests a potential trend of decreasing satisfaction with election outcomes. The 2016 election saw a stark contrast in emotional responses between voters for the two candidates. While 97% of Trump voters expressed happiness with his win, only 7% of Clinton voters shared the sentiment. This disparity in reaction is evident in the feelings of pride and hopefulness as well, with significantly higher percentages among Trump voters ![Emotional reactions of different voter groups](image5). Interestingly, despite a smaller proportion of voters expressing happiness in 2016 compared to 2008, both elections saw similar voter turnout rates ![Voter turnout in U.S. presidential elections](image3).  A significant 73% of voters admitted to being surprised by Trump's victory, with a staggering 87% of Clinton voters expressing surprise, compared to 60% of Trump voters [10]. This surprise factor is evident in the high percentage of "surprised" voters across all categories ![Surprise levels among different voter groups](image4). After Trump's victory, the most common emotions were hopefulness (51%), uneasiness (53%), sadness (41%), and fear (41%) [2].  In conclusion, the 2016 election evoked more polarized reactions compared to previous elections, particularly concerning hopefulness and disappointment. Although hopefulness was the most prevalent emotion overall, a significant portion of the electorate experienced negative emotions like uneasiness, sadness, and fear.

Trump voters overwhelmingly reported feeling hopeful about Trump's election, with 96% stating this sentiment [3]. In stark contrast, Clinton voters predominantly expressed negative emotions, with 90% feeling uneasy ![This bar chart shows the percentage of Clinton supporters who reported different feelings about Trump’s election, with the most common feeling being uneasy at 90%.](image1).  Clinton voters were more likely to express anger and sadness if they had college degrees [6].

Despite these disparate emotional responses, there was a degree of pragmatism among some Clinton voters.  While 58% were willing to give Trump a chance, a substantial 39% couldn't envision doing so [7]. This skepticism is reflected in their expectations for Trump's first term, with only 15% believing it would be successful, compared to 76% who anticipated it would be unsuccessful [10].  This negativity surpasses the sentiment observed among McCain supporters toward Obama's first term in 2008 [10]. 

In conclusion, while Trump's election evoked predominantly positive feelings among his supporters, it triggered largely negative reactions from Clinton voters, a sentiment reflected in their low expectations for his presidency.

Clinton voters expressed highly negative evaluations of Trump throughout the campaign [1]. In the wake of Trump's election, there is little sign of concern among his voters about the type of president he will be [8]. ![This bar graph from a voter callback survey shows that 10% of respondents have serious concerns about Trump's presidency, while 88% are confident.](image1)   An overwhelming  97%  of Trump voters expect him to have a successful first term [6]. By contrast, Clinton voters express little or no confidence in Trump to deal with major issues [10].  ![This bar chart compares the percentage of voters' satisfaction for winning and losing candidates from the U.S. elections in 2016 and 2008. In 2016, 97% of Trump voters and 15% of Clinton voters were satisfied. In 2008, 92% of Obama voters and 39% of McCain voters were satisfied.](image5) However, these views largely divide along lines of support [7]. ![This image is a bar graph showing that 84% of Trump voters and 20% of Clinton voters preferred their leader giving equal priority to all Americans.](image2) And while a majority of Clinton voters (58%) say they are “willing to give Trump a chance and see how he governs as president,” nearly four-in-ten (39%) say they can’t see themselves giving Trump a chance “because of the kind of person he has shown himself to be.” [10] ![This image shows that 39% of respondents can't see themselves giving Trump a chance as president because of the kind of person he has shown himself to be, while 58% are willing to give him a chance to see how he governs.](image3) Trump voters are overwhelmingly optimistic and confident about the success of Trump's first term, while Clinton voters are notably less confident and willing to accept Trump's presidency.

![Percentages of different priorities for Trump's presidency among all voters, Trump voters, and Clinton voters](image1)  Among voters, the top priorities for Trump's presidency were healthcare/Obamacare [1], the economy, immigration/securing the border, unifying the country, and jobs/unemployment [4]. However, the priorities differed between Trump and Clinton voters. For instance, 29% of Trump voters considered healthcare a priority, while only 12% of Clinton voters shared this view [1]. This difference is further emphasized in [6], which states that Trump voters were more likely to mention repealing the Affordable Care Act, while Clinton voters were more likely to mention maintaining or fixing it. 

![Opinions on the clarity of a political figure's goals, broken down by all voters, Trump voters, and Clinton voters.](image2) This suggests that Trump voters were more focused on repealing the Affordable Care Act, while Clinton voters were more concerned with maintaining or improving the existing healthcare system. Additionally, 87% of Trump voters believed they had a good idea of Trump's direction for the country, while 84% of Clinton voters felt his goals were unclear [5]. This difference in perception highlights the polarization between these two voter groups and their contrasting views on Trump's leadership. Clinton voters, for example, were more likely to prioritize Trump addressing divisions and changing his personal behavior [8]. This suggests that they viewed his leadership as divisive and hoped for a more unifying approach. In contrast, Trump voters seemed to have a clearer understanding of his agenda and were more aligned with his proposed policies, particularly those related to healthcare, the economy, and immigration [6]. This suggests that Trump voters were more likely to view his leadership favorably and believed in his ability to enact their desired changes. Clinton voters, on the other hand, appeared less certain about his direction and more apprehensive about the potential consequences of his leadership.

In conclusion, the priorities for Trump's presidency differed significantly between Trump and Clinton voters, reflecting their contrasting views on his leadership and policies.

A significant number of voters believed that the 2016 election would negatively impact race relations in the U.S.  [3]. This divide is further emphasized when we look at the responses from Trump and Clinton voters. In conclusion, while the 2016 election brought about pessimism regarding race relations, expectations for partisan relations were more balanced, and there was a general belief that enthusiastic supporters wouldn't hinder a president's effectiveness.

Republican and Republican-leaning voters have consistently favored a more conservative direction for their party, with a steady  $60\%$  supporting this view in recent years [4]. This trend is visualized in ![This chart illustrates the percentage of "More moderate" vs. "More conservative" voters from 2008 to 2016.](image2), showing minimal fluctuation in their conservative stance. On the other hand, Democratic voters are now more inclined towards a liberal approach, with  $49\%$  supporting a more liberal direction [7]. This marks a significant shift from previous years, as highlighted in ![This chart illustrates the percentage of "More moderate" vs. "More liberal" voters from 2008 to 2016.](image3), where the desire for a more liberal stance has increased considerably since the 2008 and 2012 elections. 

Following the 2016 election, there's a clear divide in reactions.  $94\%$  of Trump voters are happy with the Republican party retaining Congressional control, while  $87\%$  of Clinton voters are unhappy with the outcome [8]. This stark contrast is depicted in ![This chart displays voter sentiment ("Unhappy" vs. "Happy") following an unspecified event, categorized by "All voters," "Trump voters," and "Clinton voters."](image5), illustrating the polarization in reactions to the election results.  Despite their differing views, a significant portion of voters,  $59\%$, believe Democrats should work with Trump [4].  However, a closer look at ![This chart presents voter opinions on whether to work with Trump or stand up to him, categorized by "All voters," "Trump voters," "Clinton voters," and further segmented within "Clinton voters" by their willingness to give Trump a chance.](image4) reveals a sharp partisan divide, with Clinton voters showing a stronger preference for standing up to Trump. 

In conclusion, while Republicans have remained consistently conservative, Democrats have shifted towards a more liberal stance, and these contrasting viewpoints are clearly reflected in their reactions to the 2016 election results.

In 2008, a significant majority of both Obama and McCain voters, [9] 78% and 76% respectively, believed that their party leaders should prioritize working with the opposing party, even if it meant potentially disappointing their own supporters. This sentiment was echoed in the period following Obama's victory. [10] Nearly six-in-ten (59%) of Republicans supported GOP leaders working with Obama, while only 36% preferred a more oppositional approach. ![Republicans were more inclined to support their party leaders working with Obama in 2008.](image1)

However, the 2016 election painted a starkly different picture.  [8]  Democratic support for cooperating with Trump paled in comparison to GOP support for working with Obama eight years prior.  This shift in attitude is evident in the finding that [4] 65% of Democrats favored their leaders taking a strong stance against Trump, even if it meant hindering progress in Washington, as opposed to the mere 32% who prioritized collaboration. This stark contrast underscores a significant shift in voter expectations and a decline in the perceived importance of bipartisan cooperation. 

In conclusion, the 2008 election saw a greater emphasis on cooperation between parties, while 2016 marked a shift towards a more partisan approach, with voters expecting their leaders to prioritize their interests even at the cost of bipartisan efforts.

Voters overwhelmingly viewed the 2016 U.S. presidential election as remarkably negative, with  $92\%$  believing there was more "mudslinging" than in previous elections [7]. Americans' ratings of the government’s efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism are now lower than at any point since the September 2001 terrorist attacks [2]. For the first time, more now say the government is doing not too well or not at all well in reducing the threat of terrorism (52%) than say the government is doing either very or fairly well (46%) [2].  Positive ratings have fallen 26 points since January (when 72% said very/fairly well) [2].  Concern over government restrictions on civil liberties has fallen dramatically since July 2013, following Edward Snowden’s leaked details about NSA surveillance programs [8]. At that time, more expressed concern that government policies had gone too far restricting civil liberties (47%) than that they did not go far enough to protect the country (35%) [8]. ![The image is a line graph comparing two perspectives over a period from 2004 to 2015.](image3)  By two-to-one, Americans now say that they are more concerned that the government’s anti-terror policies have not gone far enough to protect the country (56%), rather than that these policies have gone too far in restricting the average person’s civil liberties (28%) [10]. Since the start of the year, there has been a seven percentage-point rise in the share expressing concern that these policies have not gone far enough [10]. Older and less educated Americans are somewhat more likely than younger and more highly educated Americans to give the government low marks for the job it is doing reducing the threat of terrorism [9]. ![The table displays survey results on opinions about the balance between civil liberties and national protection across different age groups.](image2) Among those 50 and older, a majority (57%) say the government is not doing well reducing the  terrorist threat (42% say that it is) [6]. In contrast, 46% of younger adults (those 18-29 years old) give the government’s performance a negative rating, while 53% say it is doing very or fairly well [6]. Public perceptions of government efforts to combat terrorism have become more negative over time, with older Americans and Republicans expressing greater concern that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough.

Older and less educated Americans are more likely to view the government's efforts to combat terrorism negatively [6].  This pattern is consistent across age groups, with those 65 and older exhibiting the highest levels of concern about national security over civil liberties [3]. ![The table shows that older age groups are more likely to feel that the government has not gone far enough to protect the U.S.](image2)  In contrast, younger adults, particularly those aged 18-29, demonstrate greater concern for civil liberties and express more worry about the U.S. becoming overly involved in conflicts [1]. This suggests a generational divide in prioritizing national security versus individual freedoms.

![The graph shows that Republican approval ratings have generally declined over time, while Democratic approval ratings remain higher.](image1) While [7] notes that assessments of counterterrorism efforts have become more negative across the political spectrum, Republicans show a steeper decline in positive views compared to Democrats. This trend aligns with the observation from [7] that Democrats are now the only partisan group with a majority expressing positive views of the government's performance on this issue.

![The graph indicates that the percentage of people who believe the government has not gone far enough to protect the country has increased over time, while the percentage who believe the government has gone too far in restricting civil liberties has decreased.](image5) This shift in public opinion over time further highlights the complex interplay of age, political ideology, and perceptions of government action in response to perceived threats.

In conclusion, older Americans and those with less education tend to view government counterterrorism efforts less favorably, prioritizing security over civil liberties. This contrasts with younger generations who are more likely to prioritize civil liberties.  Political ideology also plays a role, with Republicans showing a greater decline in positive views of the government's handling of terrorism compared to Democrats.

[4] Among those 50 and older, a majority   $(57\%)$   say the government is not doing well reducing the  terrorist threat (  $42\%$   say that it is). In contrast,   $46\%$   of younger adults (those 18-29 years old) give the government’s performance a negative rating, while   $53\%$   say it is doing very or fairly well.  Older adults are more likely to perceive the government as not doing well in reducing the terrorist threat compared to younger adults. ![The table displays survey results on opinions about the balance between civil liberties and national protection across different age groups.](image5) This difference in perception aligns with their views on anti-terror policies, where older age groups (65+ at 71%) are more likely to believe that these policies haven't gone far enough to protect the country. Conversely, younger adults are more evenly split, with 43% feeling that policies go too far in restricting civil liberties and 44% believing they don't go far enough. Older age groups are more concerned about security, while younger adults are more divided on the balance between security and civil liberties. In conclusion, older age groups perceive the government as less effective in reducing the terrorist threat and are more likely to support stronger anti-terror policies, potentially at the expense of civil liberties, compared to younger adults.

Public concerns about anti-terrorism policies restricting civil liberties have shifted significantly over time.  In 2004, a larger percentage of the population believed the government hadn't gone far enough in its anti-terrorism efforts [2]. ![The graph shows a shift in public opinion over time towards thinking the government has gone too far in restricting civil liberties](image2)  However, by 2015, the majority opinion flipped, with more people feeling the government had gone too far [2]. This shift is particularly noticeable after events like the failed Christmas Day terrorist attack in 2010, which saw a spike in concern about the government's lack of action [9].  This trend is further reflected in the age demographics. While adults under 30 are split on whether the government is doing enough or going too far, older age groups increasingly believe that the government should prioritize security over civil liberties [8]. ![The table shows that older age groups are more likely to believe the government should prioritize security over civil liberties](image4)  This difference in opinion is also apparent when considering political affiliations. In 2015, 71% of Republicans felt the government wasn't doing enough to combat terrorism [3].  ![The graph shows that Republicans are more likely than Democrats or Independents to believe the government should prioritize security over civil liberties](image3) This contrasts with Democrats, where opinions are more divided, especially among liberal Democrats who are equally concerned about government overreach and security [7].  Overall, while the perception of government efforts to combat terrorism has declined across all demographics since 2001, the preferred balance between security and civil liberties remains a point of contention across different age groups and political ideologies [6]. How have opinions on government anti-terrorism efforts among different age groups evolved over time, and how do these opinions compare across political affiliations?  Older age groups and Republicans are more likely to prioritize security over civil liberties, while younger generations and Democrats hold more diverse views.

Public perception of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS has remained largely unchanged in terms of its immediate progress, with a consistent majority [4] viewing the effort as "not too well" or "not at all well" ![The bar chart illustrates the percentage of people rating the campaign as "not too/at all well" or "Very/Fairly well" remained consistent from October 2014 to December 2015.](image4). However, there has been a notable increase in optimism regarding the long-term success of the campaign. While only 55% believed the U.S. and its allies would likely succeed in July 2015, this figure rose to 66% by December 2015 [9] ![The bar charts highlight the positive shift in public opinion about the campaign's likely success from July 2015 to December 2015.](image5).  Despite this overall positive trend, a partisan divide exists. While a majority across Republicans (65%), Democrats (72%), and Independents (62%) believe in the eventual success of the campaign, Democrats are more likely than Republicans and Independents to view the campaign as currently going well (45% vs. 33% and 26% respectively) [2]. This partisan gap is further highlighted by concerns about the extent of U.S. involvement. Republicans are significantly more likely to worry about the U.S. not taking sufficient action against ISIS (75%), while only 18% fear excessive involvement. This contrasts with Democrats, where a greater proportion (although not a majority) express concern about the U.S. becoming too involved [10] ![This bar chart depicts the variation in opinion about the policy's effectiveness across different age groups and political affiliations.](image3). Interestingly, despite Republicans' inclination towards greater military action against ISIS, they are more likely than Democrats to perceive it as a major threat to the U.S [1]. ![This bar chart shows that a higher percentage of Republicans perceive ISIS as a major threat compared to Democrats.](image1). It is worth noting that these trends have remained relatively stable throughout 2015, even in the aftermath of significant events like the attacks in Paris and San Bernardino [8]. ![This line graph illustrates the steady approval and disapproval ratings for the U.S. military campaign against ISIS from August 2014 to December 2015.](image2). In conclusion, while public assessment of the immediate progress of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS has remained largely unchanged, there is a growing optimism about its eventual success, although this optimism is tempered by partisan divisions regarding the level of U.S. involvement.

Public views on whether Islam is more likely than other religions to encourage violence have been closely divided for much of the past decade [3]. Currently,  46% of the public believe that Islam is more likely to encourage violence, while 45% believe it is not [3]. This partisan divide is evident in the stark differences between Democrats and Republicans.  A historical high of 68% of Republicans say Islam encourages violence more than other religions, a view largely unchanged since last fall [9].  This sentiment among Republicans has been increasing steadily since 2002.  ![The image is a line graph showing the popularity or proportion of three political affiliations over time, likely based on some form of polling or registration data. The red line represents the Republican affiliation, which starts at 33% in 2002 and rises to 68% by 2015.](image1)  In contrast, only 30% of Democrats share this view, marking a 12 percentage point decrease since September 2014 [9].  

Despite a wide rejection of increased scrutiny on U.S. Muslims solely due to their religion [8], this partisan divide over Islam's relationship with violence has significant implications for how different groups perceive the government's handling of terrorism.  With Republicans increasingly associating Islam with violence, there's a corresponding decline in their confidence in the government's counterterrorism efforts. Only 27% of Republicans believe the government is effectively reducing the terrorist threat, a significant drop from 63% at the beginning of the year [6]. This suggests a potential link between perceptions of Islam and assessments of government action on terrorism.  ![The image is a line graph that displays two sets of data over a period of time from 2001 to 2015. The two lines represent contrasting categories:

1. "Very/Fairly well" is marked with a lighter gold line.
2. "Not too/Not at all well" is marked with a darker gold line.

The y-axis represents percentage values, although it is not explicitly labeled in the image. The x-axis denotes years, with intervals of two years, starting from 2001 (denoted as '01') and ending at 2015 (denoted as '15').

Key data points from the graph include:
- In 2001, "Very/Fairly well" starts at 88%, while "Not too/Not at all well" starts at 8%.
- There is a noticeable crossing of lines around 2007, where "Very/Fairly well" decreases and "Not too/Not at all well" increases.
- By 2015, "Very/Fairly well" is at 46% and "Not too/Not at all well" is at 52%.](image3) Republicans' increasingly negative outlook towards the government's counterterrorism measures coincides with their heightened perception of Islam as encouraging violence.

Republicans' perception of Islam's relationship with violence is closely tied to their diminishing confidence in the government's ability to address terrorism.

Americans are divided about whether they see Islam as more likely than other religions to encourage violence among its believers: 46% say it is more likely, while 45% say it is not more likely. [5] The share of the public saying that Islam is more likely than other religions to  encourage violence has dropped four percentage points since a historical high of  50% in September 2014. [5] For much of the past decade, public views on this measure have been closely divided. [5] ![The image is a line graph comparing two perceptions over time (from 2002 to 2015) regarding the encouragement of violence among followers of a religion versus other religions.](image5)  The partisan divide over whether Islam encourages violence is now as wide as it has ever been. [8] Fully 68% of Republicans say Islam encourages violence more than other religions, a historical high but little changed since last fall. [8] By contrast, just 30% of Democrats say Islam is more likely to encourage violence than other religions, down from 42% in September 2014, but on par with Democratic opinion at other points in recent years. [8] ![The image is a line graph depicting trends in percentages over time, from 2002 to 2015, for three groups: Republicans, Democrats, and Independents.](image1)  The survey finds that, as has been the case since 2002, the Republican Party has a sizable advantage over the Democrats on terrorism: 46% of the public says the Republican Party can do better in dealing with the terrorist threat at home, compared with 34% who favor the Democrats. [6] Perceptions of Islam encouraging violence have grown more partisan, with Republicans increasingly associating Islam with violence while Democrats show a decline, coinciding with a public perception favoring Republicans over Democrats in handling terrorism.

Conservative Republicans stand out as the only group where a majority (57%) support increased scrutiny of Muslims due to their religion. [3] This aligns with the observation that Republicans, more than Independents or Democrats, perceive terrorism as a major national issue. [4]  ![The image is a bar chart that depicts the percentage of different demographic groups who perceive scrutiny due to religion.](image2) Notably, while 49% of Republicans believe there is additional scrutiny of Muslims because of their religion, a smaller percentage (32%) report personally experiencing scrutiny based on their religious beliefs. This suggests that the perceived threat of terrorism might be influencing Republicans' views on Muslims more than their personal experiences with religious discrimination. Conversely, 87% of Liberal Democrats oppose increased scrutiny of Muslims. [2] ![The image is a bar chart showing the opinions of different political groups on whether individuals should be subject to additional scrutiny solely because of their religion.](image3) This partisan divide is further emphasized by the fact that only 23% of Democrats consider terrorism a top national issue. [4] Younger individuals (18-29) are more likely to perceive scrutiny based on religion (80%), compared to older age groups. [2]  This difference in perception across age groups could be related to generational differences in views on terrorism and national security, as younger generations may have different experiences and perspectives on these issues. In conclusion, Conservative Republicans are more likely than other political and demographic groups to support greater scrutiny of Muslims, potentially influenced by their heightened concern about terrorism.

Americans are increasingly concerned about terrorism, with [7] nearly three in ten Americans (29%) citing terrorism (18%), national security (8%), or ISIS (7%) as the most important problem facing the country today. This represents a significant increase from the previous year, when only 4% of the public cited any of these issues [7]. ![The table shows a significant increase in public concern about terrorism from December 2014 to December 2015.](image1)  This shift in public opinion is also reflected in the declining approval ratings of government efforts to combat terrorism. [3] For the first time since the September 2001 terrorist attacks, more Americans now believe that the government is not doing well in reducing the threat of terrorism (52%) than those who believe it is doing well (46%) [3].  This decline in positive ratings, a 26-point drop since January, spans across the political spectrum [4]. [4] While Democrats remain the only partisan group where a majority (64%) still approves of the government's efforts, this number has decreased from 85% in January.  Independents and Republicans have also shown a decline in confidence, with only 44% and 27% respectively approving of the government's actions [4]. This disapproval is particularly prominent among older and less educated demographics [10]. [2] For example, a majority (57%) of those aged 50 and older believe the government is not doing well in reducing the terrorist threat, compared to 46% of younger adults (18-29 years old) [2].  ![The table presents a breakdown of public perception regarding the government's performance in addressing a specific issue across various demographic groups, including age, education level, political affiliation, and ideology.](image4) These shifting perceptions highlight the growing concern about terrorism in the United States and a declining confidence in the government's ability to address it, particularly among certain demographics and political groups.  In conclusion, perceptions of terrorism have increased, while confidence in government efforts to combat it has decreased, particularly among older and less educated demographics and across political affiliations.

Republicans are more likely to prioritize terrorism and national security issues, with  $41\%$ of Republicans citing these as the most important problems facing the nation, compared to just  $23\%$  of Democrats [5]. This difference in prioritization is also evident in the significantly higher percentage of Republicans who believe that the government's anti-terrorism policies haven't gone far enough [2].  ![The table displays survey results regarding the importance of various issues to different political affiliations.](image1) In contrast, Democrats are more likely to prioritize economic issues. Notably, there's a considerable 18-point difference between Republicans and Democrats when it comes to prioritizing defense and national security.  The shift in focus towards terrorism among Republicans is evident when comparing public concerns between 2014 and 2015, where there's a significant 17% increase in the proportion of people mentioning terrorism [4]. ![The table presents survey data on public concerns in December 2014 and December 2015, with the percentage of respondents mentioning each issue and the change over the year.](image4)  This suggests a growing concern about security threats within the Republican base. In conclusion, Republicans place a higher priority on terrorism and national security, while Democrats are more concerned with economic issues.

[6] There are wide partisan divides on the most important problem facing the nation. Four-in- ten (41%) Republicans mention terrorism, defense issues and national security or ISIS, while fewer independents (28%) and Democrats (23%) cite these issues.  ![This table appears to show survey results about how different demographic groups perceive how well something is performing or being done.](image2) This difference in prioritization of terrorism as a national issue is reflected in the varying perceptions of the government's efforts to combat it. [4] Compared to early 2015, assessments of  government efforts to combat terrorism are  more negative across the political spectrum.  Democrats are now the only partisan group in  which a majority   (64%)   say the government is  doing at least fairly well (down from  85%   in  January). Independents’ positive ratings have  dropped 25 points, from  69%   to  44%  . And just   27%   of Republicans now say the government is  doing very or fairly well reducing the terrorist  threat, down from  63%   at the beginning of the  year. Republicans, who prioritize terrorism as a major issue, are the least likely to approve of the government's handling of the threat. This suggests that the perceived importance of terrorism as a national problem is linked to how different political groups judge the government's performance in addressing it. Republicans are more likely to view terrorism as a significant threat and are subsequently more critical of the government's response. Democrats, while still showing a decrease in approval, maintain a more positive view of the government's efforts. In conclusion, Republicans consider terrorism a more important issue than Democrats and are more critical of the government’s efforts to address it.

[1] states that 74% of Republicans prefer smaller government.  Independents are more divided on this issue, as shown in ![This chart compares opinions on government size and regulation across different political affiliations.](image1), with 47% favoring smaller government and 44% favoring bigger government. [6] highlights the divide in opinion regarding the fairness of the U.S. economic system, with 63% of Republicans believing it to be fair to most Americans, a stark contrast to the 85% of Democrats who believe it unfairly favors powerful interests [3]. Independents, with 66% believing the system is unfair [4], align more closely with Democrats on this issue. ![This image presents survey results regarding Americans' views on the fairness of the current system of government.](image4) further illustrates these contrasting viewpoints.  Overall, independents tend to fall somewhere between Democrats and Republicans on government regulation and economic fairness.  They are less inclined towards small government than Republicans [1], and they are more likely to see the economic system as unfair than Republicans, but less so than Democrats [3]. 
Independents' views on government regulation and economic fairness are less homogenous than those of Democrats or Republicans, often falling between the two parties' stances.

Over the past two decades, there has been a notable trend of increasing negativity towards both major political parties in the U.S. [1] This trend is reflected among independents as well, with those not leaning towards either party being most likely to hold unfavorable views of both. [8] ![The image shows a line graph with different categories of favorability towards both the Republican and Democratic parties.](image1) Specifically, while only 6% of independents viewed both parties unfavorably in 1994, this number rose to 12% by 2018. [9] Interestingly, there's a distinction among subgroups within independents. While the overall negativity towards both parties has increased among independents, the share who hold such views has actually declined in recent years, particularly among those with no leanings. [9] Independents who lean towards a particular party tend to align with the views of their respective parties, mirroring the partisan divide. [4, 10] ![The image shows a data visualization about favorable/unfavorable opinions towards political parties.](image3) For instance, 81% of Republican-leaning independents view the Democratic Party unfavorably, compared to only 3% who view the Republican Party unfavorably. [3] This partisan imprint is evident in their opinions on various issues as well. [10]  ![The image shows a line graph depicting the unfavorable view towards both parties from 1994 to 2018.](image4) Notably, the intensity of dislike towards the opposing party has also surged among both Democrats and Republicans, as well as among their respective leaning independents. [6, 7] For example, the share of Democratic-leaning independents with a very unfavorable view of the Republican Party has increased considerably, from 8% in 1994 to 37% in 2018. [6] In conclusion, while unfavorable views towards both parties have generally increased among independents, the trend is more pronounced among those who lean towards a specific party, highlighting the growing polarization within the American political landscape.

Over the past two decades, both Republicans and Democrats have increasingly viewed the opposing party more negatively [8]. This trend of escalating negativity towards the other party is mirrored among independents who lean towards either the Republican or Democratic parties [8]. ![The image illustrates increasing polarization over the years, with growing unfavorable views of the opposite party among partisan groups.](image4)  For instance, in 1994, only 8% of Democratic-leaning independents held a very unfavorable opinion of the Republican Party. However, by 2018, this number had skyrocketed to 37% [2]. Similarly, Republican-leaning independents saw a dramatic increase in unfavorable views towards the Democratic Party, rising from 15% in 1994 to 39% in 2018 [2].  This polarization is evident across party lines, with 87% of Republicans viewing the Democratic Party unfavorably and 88% of Democrats viewing the Republican Party unfavorably in recent times [3].  Republican-leaning independents are nearly as likely as Republicans to hold negative views of the Democratic Party (81% unfavorable), while Democratic-leaning independents closely mirror Democrats in their unfavorable views of the Republican Party (84% unfavorable) [3]. Interestingly, while a significant percentage of independents view both parties unfavorably, the share has declined in recent years. In 2015, over a third (36%) of independents held unfavorable views of both parties, indicating a potential softening of extreme polarization [9].  ![The image is a data visualization that shows the percentage of people who have favorable or unfavorable opinions of the Republican and Democratic parties, broken down by different political affiliations.](image1) Currently, 28% of independents have an unfavorable opinion of both parties, compared to 10% of Republicans and 9% of Democrats [4].  Among independents who do not lean towards a specific party, 37% hold unfavorable views of both parties [6], highlighting a more pronounced trend of disillusionment with the existing party system. Only 11% of these independents favor the Democratic Party, with a similarly low 9% favoring the Republican Party [6]. In conclusion, while polarization has intensified over time, recent data suggests a potential decrease in extreme negative views among independents towards both parties, with 28% currently holding unfavorable opinions of both.

Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are significantly more likely than Democrats and Democratic leaners to have a very unfavorable view of China [4]. Around two-thirds (64%) of Americans say China has done a bad job, including 43% who say it has done a very bad job [2]. ![The image is a bar chart displaying survey results on people's perceptions of something categorized as "Bad" or "Good" across different demographic groups.](image1) Republicans and those who lean toward the GOP are about twice as likely (71%) as Democrats and Democratic leaners (37%) to say the U.S. should hold China responsible even at the expense of worse economic relations [9].  Republicans are significantly more likely to view China's handling of the coronavirus negatively and favor holding them responsible, even if it harms economic ties.

Republicans are significantly more likely than Democrats to view China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic negatively [10]. Specifically, 82% of Republicans believe China has done a bad job, with 61% stating they believe China has done a *very* bad job. In contrast, only 54% of Democrats share this sentiment, with only 30% believing China's handling of the pandemic was *very* bad [10]. This partisan gap is evident in how Americans believe the U.S. should approach its relationship with China in light of the pandemic. While 38% of Americans overall believe the U.S. should prioritize holding China responsible for its role in the outbreak, even if it harms economic relations, Republicans are almost twice as likely (71%) to support this stance compared to Democrats (37%) [3].  ![The image displays survey data on U.S. public opinion regarding holding China responsible for the coronavirus outbreak and its potential impact on U.S.-China relations.](image1) This difference in opinion extends to how Americans view the U.S.-China relationship more broadly. ![The image illustrates trends in the percentage of Republicans and Democrats who view U.S.-China economic relations as "bad" from 2005 to 2020.](image2) While both Democrats and Republicans have grown increasingly negative towards China over time, the shift among Republicans is more pronounced.  In 2019, Republicans were almost evenly split on whether economic ties with China were good or bad. However, by 2020, a clear majority (63%) viewed the relationship negatively, marking a 15-point increase [4]. This trend is reflected more generally in American attitudes, with 68% of Americans viewing U.S.-China economic relations as bad in 2020, compared to 53% in 2019 ![The image presents a line graph showing the change in the percentage of people viewing U.S.-China relations as "Bad" and "Good" from 2019 to 2020.](image3). This growing negativity is especially pronounced among older Americans, with 73% of those aged 50 and above viewing the relationship as bad [4] and 73% disapproving of China's pandemic response [10]. ![The image presents a bar chart comparing perceptions of an unspecified issue as "Bad" or "Good" across different age groups and political affiliations.](image4)  Overall, Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the COVID-19 outbreak than Democrats, and these negative perceptions have intensified over time, particularly among older Republicans.

A survey of U.S. adults conducted by the Pew Research Center [7] reveals stark differences in how Americans perceive China's role in the coronavirus outbreak and its implications for U.S.-China relations. The survey found that a significant majority of Americans attribute blame to China for the global spread of the virus.  Specifically, 78% believe that the Chinese government's initial handling of the outbreak in Wuhan contributed to the pandemic's spread [4]. This sentiment is reflected in the finding that half of Americans believe the U.S. should hold China accountable for its role, even if it jeopardizes economic ties [7]. ![The image shows a bar chart illustrating that 51% of Americans believe the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the outbreak, even if it means worsening economic relations.](image1) This suggests a willingness among a substantial portion of the American public to prioritize accountability over potential economic repercussions.

The survey highlights a distinct partisan divide in these views.  Republicans are notably more critical of China's handling of the outbreak, with 73% attributing a "great deal" of responsibility to China's early actions, compared to 38% of Democrats [4]. This partisan gap is further evident in the sentiment towards holding China accountable. Republicans are twice as likely as Democrats (71% vs. 37%) to support holding China responsible, even if it leads to strained economic relations [7]. ![The image is a horizontal bar graph showing that a majority of respondents (51%) believe something is "A great deal" the case, highlighting a strong leaning towards this option.](image2) This difference in opinion likely reflects broader partisan disagreements on foreign policy and China's role on the world stage.

Furthermore, the survey data reveals age to be another demographic factor influencing perceptions of China. Older Americans are more likely to hold negative views towards China [8], indicating a potential generational divide in how China is perceived.  ![The image displays a bar chart depicting survey results on perceptions categorized as "Bad" or "Good" across age and political affiliation.](image3) 

In conclusion, Americans are divided on China's role in the coronavirus outbreak and its implications for U.S.-China relations, with these divisions largely falling along partisan lines and age groups.
