Americans' views of China have become increasingly negative over time, with older Americans and Republicans holding more unfavorable views than younger Americans and Democrats.

Around three-quarters $(73\%)$ of Americans  have an unfavorable view of China today – the  most negative reading in the 15 years that Pew  Research Center has been measuring these  views [8]. This July survey also marks the third  survey over the past two years in which  unfavorable views of China have reached  historic highs. Negative views have increased by  7 percentage points over the last four months  alone and have shot up 26 points since 2018 [8]. ![The image is a line graph showing trends from 2005 to 2020. It tracks two groups:

1. **Rep/Lean Rep** (in red): Starts at 39 in 2005, fluctuates, and peaks at 83 in 2020.
2. **Dem/Lean Dem** (in blue): Starts at 34 in 2005, fluctuates, and reaches 68 in 2020.

The graph indicates changes over time in percentages or scores associated with these groups.](image5) Older Americans turn even more negative toward  China in recent months [3]. While majorities of every age  group now have an unfavorable  view of China, Americans ages  50 and older are substantially  more negative  $(81\%)$   than those  ages 30 to 49  $(71\%)$   or those  under 30   $(56\%)$  [5]. For those ages  50 and older, this represents an  increase of 10 percentage  points since March [5].  ![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of people with favorable and unfavorable views across different age groups and political affiliations.](image2) Negative opinions of China have been increasing across all age groups, but particularly among older Americans and Republicans.

![This image is a bar chart showing the percentage of people with favorable and unfavorable views across different age groups and political affiliations.](image2)  Around three-quarters of Americans say the Chinese government’s initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan contributed either a great deal $(51\%)$ or a fair amount $(27\%)$ to the global spread of the virus. [3] Republicans are particularly critical: $73\%$ believe China’s early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its spread, compared with $38\%$ of Democrats who say the same. [3] Older people, too, are more critical, with $73\%$ of those ages 50 and older finding fault in China’s pandemic response, compared with $59\%$ of those 30 to 49 and $54\%$ of those under 30. [1] ![This image is a line graph showing trends over time from 2005 to 2020. It tracks three age groups: "18-29," "30-49," and "50 and older." Each age group is represented by a different colored line.](image1) Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are significantly more likely than Democrats and Democratic leaners to say China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus: $82\%$ vs. $54\%$, respectively. [1]  ![This image is a line graph showing trends from 2005 to 2020. It tracks two groups: ](image3)  In the past four months, negative views toward China among Republicans have increased 11 percentage points.  Over the same period, unfavorable views among Democrats have increased 6 points, resulting in a 15 point gap between the parties. [10] Older Americans and Republicans are more likely to view China's handling of COVID-19 negatively, while younger age groups and Democrats hold less critical views.

[8] In the U.S., political affiliation dictates who people think is the most important foreign policy partner. While both Republicans and Democrats agree that the UK is their most important partner, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are keener on Israel as a partner $(26\%)$ than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents $(9\%)$. Democrats also place more emphasis on Canada and Mexico for their top foreign policy affiliate. However, views of Germany are similar among partisans in the U.S., with both sides ranking Germany fifth on the list of most or second-most important foreign policy partners.   [3] Democrats in the U.S. are more likely to want greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans. And in Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU are more willing to want greater cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD. This jibes with data on the international image of the U.S., where those on the ideological right in Germany tend to be more favorable toward the U.S. overall. Closer ties with Russia and China? [9] For Germans of differing political stripes, the differences are less dramatic. Supporters of the CDU/CSU, as well as those who support the SPD and Greens, name France as the first or second-most important partner, followed by the U.S. ![The chart shows the percentage of respondents from different political affiliations in the US who consider certain countries as their top or second most important foreign policy partner.](image1)  In the US, Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel as a foreign policy partner compared to Democrats, while both parties largely agree on the UK and Germany.  ![The chart shows the percentage of respondents from different political affiliations in Germany who consider certain countries as their top or second most important foreign policy partner.](image2) In Germany, there is a greater degree of consensus across political lines, with France and the US being the top two preferred partners for all major parties. Political affiliations in the U.S. play a more significant role in shaping preferences for foreign policy partners, particularly regarding Israel, compared to Germany where there's broader agreement on key partners like France and the U.S..

When asked about their preferences for a close relationship with Russia or Germany, a significant majority of Americans (61%) favored Germany, while only 26% chose Russia. ![This image is a bar chart comparing the opinions of Americans and Germans regarding two different questions.](image2)  However, Germans showed a smaller gap, with 39% preferring the U.S. and 25% favoring Russia [8].  This difference in opinion is further highlighted by the fact that Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to desire greater collaboration with Russia [3]. 

Interestingly, there's a distinct East-West divide in Germany regarding Russia. ![The image is a bar chart comparing the preferences of people from two regions, labeled "West" and "East," regarding the U.S., Russia, or Both (VOL). The bar is divided into sections representing each choice, with different colors for each.](image4) While 43% in West Germany prefer a closer relationship with the U.S. compared to 21% for Russia, East Germany shows a contrasting preference with 38% for Russia and 23% for the U.S. [1]. This suggests a lingering influence of historical ties and experiences on contemporary geopolitical preferences within Germany.

When it comes to China, Germans are nearly twice as likely as Americans to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% vs. 24%) [10]. This contrasts with the near-equal split in the U.S. where 41% prefer Germany and 44% favor China. ![This image is a bar chart comparing the opinions of Americans and Germans regarding two different questions.](image2)  This difference is notable as it indicates a greater willingness among Americans to engage with China, even if it may come at the expense of closer ties with a traditional European ally like Germany.

Political affiliations add another layer to these preferences. Republicans in the U.S. are more likely than Democrats to favor increased cooperation with Russia (41% vs. 32%) [3]. Similarly, in Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more inclined towards greater cooperation with the U.S. compared to supporters of the Greens and the SPD [9].  ![The image is a chart comparing political party alignment with some numerical percentages in the U.S. and Germany. The chart uses horizontal lines to represent a 0-100% scale for party alignment or approval.](image3)  These partisan divisions underscore how domestic political alignments can significantly influence foreign policy preferences, highlighting the complexities of international relations in an increasingly multipolar world.

In conclusion, Americans express a stronger preference for close ties with Germany over Russia and China, while Germans are more open to cooperation with Russia and less enthusiastic about China compared to their American counterparts. These preferences are further influenced by political affiliations in both countries.

While both Republicans and Democrats in the U.S. consider the UK their most important foreign policy partner, there are notable differences in their views towards other countries. [4] For instance, Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel as a partner compared to Democrats. [4] This partisan divide is also evident in attitudes towards Russia and Germany. A greater percentage of Republicans favor close ties with Russia than with Germany, while the opposite is true for Democrats. [5] ![This image is a bar chart comparing the opinions of Americans and Germans regarding two different questions.](image5) This difference in opinion aligns with the broader observation that conservative Americans tend to view Russia more favorably than liberal Americans. [7] Interestingly, this ideological divide is less pronounced in Germany. [7]  When it comes to China, Germans express a strong preference for a close relationship with the U.S. over China. [6] However, Americans are almost evenly split on whether they prefer closer ties with Germany or China. [6] Notably, younger Americans are more likely to prioritize a close relationship with China over Germany compared to older Americans. [10] In conclusion, political party preferences in the U.S. and, to a lesser extent, Germany, significantly influence attitudes toward cooperation with Russia and China.

When looking at attitudes toward cooperation with Russia, Germans are almost twice as likely as  Americans to want greater collaboration [2]. Increased cooperation with Russia is a more common  preference among Republicans in the U.S.   $\left(41\%\right)$   than Democrats  $\left(32\%\right)$  , as well as among  Germans living in former East Germany   $(75\%)$   than in the former West   $(63\%)$  [2].  Among Germans, there is far more support for  a close relationship with Russia in the former  East than in the former West [7]. ![Germans in the former East prioritize relations with Russia over U.S.](image1) Nearly four-in- ten East Germans say that they prefer close ties  with Russia, compared with only   $23\%$   who say  the same about the U.S [7]. And West Germans are  twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with  the U.S. than with Russia [7]. In the U.S., Republicans are more likely to favor cooperation with Russia than Democrats, while in Germany, support is higher in the former East than West [2, 7].

When asked which country is the world’s leading economic power, Americans and Germans give  starkly different answers [2]. Half of Americans name the U.S., with about a third   $(32\%)$   choosing  China [2]. However, roughly half of Germans name China $(53\%)$ as the leading economic power  compared with $24\%$ who name the U.S. [2]. ![The image appears to be a bar chart comparing various percentages related to the U.S., China, Japan, and the EU.](image4)  Relatively few in both countries see Japan or the countries  of the European Union as the leading economic power, although  $14\%$   in Germany name the EU,  about twice as many as in the U.S. [2]. Americans and Germans also hold different  opinions on countries and international  organizations [8]. On balance, Germans tend to  view these nations and organizations more  positively than Americans [8]. This divide is  starkest when it comes to views of the EU [8].  While roughly seven-in-ten Germans favor the  union, only about half of Americans agree [8]. ![The image is a comparative bar chart showing approval ratings of five international entities (EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO) from the perspectives of three groups: U.S., a 32-country median, and Germany.](image5)  A  similarly wide gap exists between German and  American perceptions of Russia, though  favorable opinions of Russia are less  widespread in both countries than positive  views of the UN and EU [8]. Americans and Germans have significantly different opinions on which country is the leading economic power, with Americans favoring the U.S. and Germans favoring China, and Germans generally hold more favorable views towards international entities, particularly the EU, compared to Americans.

Americans and Germans hold differing views on which country is the world's leading economic power [7]. Half of Americans believe it to be the U.S., while only 24% of Germans share this view. In contrast, 53% of Germans perceive China as the leading economic power, compared to 32% of Americans ![The image appears to be a bar chart comparing various percentages related to the U.S., China, Japan, and the EU.](image2).  This difference in perception likely stems from varying economic perspectives and experiences. 

Germans tend to hold more favorable opinions of international organizations like the EU and UN compared to Americans [10]. This is evident in the significantly higher approval rating of the EU among Germans (69%) compared to Americans (51%) ![The image is a comparative bar chart showing approval ratings of five international entities (EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO) from the perspectives of three groups: U.S., a 32-country median, and Germany.](image1). Political ideology plays a significant role in shaping these perceptions [3]. For instance, conservative Americans and Germans tend to view Russia more favorably than their liberal counterparts, while the latter group holds more positive views of the UN and EU ![The image is a comparative chart showing the opinions of Americans and Germans towards the United Nations (UN), European Union (EU), and Russia.](image4). 

Furthermore, historical context influences these opinions, particularly among Germans [5]. Those living in former East Germany tend to view Russia more favorably and the EU less favorably than those in the former West ![The image is a bar chart comparing the preferences of people from two regions, labeled "West" and "East," regarding the U.S., Russia, or Both (VOL).](image5). This suggests that past experiences with these entities continue to shape contemporary perceptions. In conclusion, Americans and Germans diverge in their views of international organizations and economic powers due to a complex interplay of economic perspectives, political ideologies, and historical contexts.

Americans and Germans hold contrasting views on the use of military force.  About eight-in-ten Americans believe it is sometimes necessary to use force to maintain  order in the world [4]. However, only about half of Germans share this viewpoint [4]. This difference in perception extends to their views on defense spending as well. While half of Americans believe European allies should maintain their current level of defense spending [1], Germans are divided on whether to increase or maintain their defense budget, with about four-in-ten supporting each option [5]. ![Germans are split between increasing or maintaining defense spending](image1) Despite these differences, young people in both countries hold more favorable opinions of the U.S.-Germany relationship [8]. For instance, 82% of Americans aged 18 to 29 view the relationship positively, compared to 73% of those 65 and older [2].  Similarly,  40% of young Germans view relations with the U.S. positively, compared to only 31% of those aged 65 and older [2]. In conclusion, while Americans are more inclined towards the use of military force and maintaining current defense spending levels, Germans are more divided on these issues. However, younger generations in both countries view the U.S.-Germany relationship more favorably than their older counterparts.

Americans [6] are far more likely than Germans to believe that military force is sometimes necessary to maintain world order (eight-in-ten Americans versus about half of Germans). This difference in opinion is also reflected in their views on NATO.  ![The chart shows the opinions of Americans and Germans on whether their country should use military force to defend a NATO ally, with 60% of Americans supporting and 60% of Germans opposing.](image1) Notably, only about half of Germans believe that American military bases are important for their country’s national security [5]. Conversely, a striking 85% of Americans see U.S. military bases in Germany as important to their own country’s security [3]. 

Although fewer Americans now than in 2017 feel that European allies should bolster their national defense spending [8], Americans are still more likely than Germans to favor increased defense spending in Europe [7].  ![The chart illustrates the trend of Americans and Germans' opinions on national defense spending from 2017 to 2019.](image4)  In conclusion, Americans are more likely than Germans to support military intervention and increased defense spending.

When asked whether European allies should increase, decrease, or maintain their defense spending, half of Americans in a 2019 poll said spending levels should remain the same [5]. This is a notable shift from 2017 when 45% of Americans felt their allies in Europe should dedicate more resources to national defense [5]. ![The image is a comparative bar chart that depicts the public opinion of Americans and Germans on national defense spending over the years 2017, 2018, and 2019.](image5)  In Germany, the public is divided on whether to increase or maintain current levels of spending on national defense, with about four-in-ten taking each view in 2019 [7]. Similar to the trend in the U.S., German views on this issue have changed since 2017 when about half of Germans were content with their country’s defense spending, while about a third felt it should be increased [7]. Within the U.S., Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to favor increased defense spending in Europe compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [8]. However, the share of Republicans who think U.S.’s European allies should increase their defense budgets has fallen by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [8]. ![The image is a line graph showing trends over three years, from 2017 to 2019, for two political affiliations: "Republican/Lean Rep" and "Democrat/Lean Dem." ](image2) In Germany, there are partisan gaps in opinions on defense spending, with supporters of the CDU/CSU favoring increases, supporters of the Greens expressing more skepticism, and members of the SPD falling in the middle [1]. ![The image is a horizontal bar chart displaying numerical values associated with three different political parties. The parties listed are CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens. The numbers next to each party indicate specific values: CDU/CSU has 51, SPD has 41, and Greens have 28. The chart is likely used to represent poll results, seats in a parliament, or other similar data related to these political parties.](image4)  Both American and German opinions on defense spending have shifted since 2017, with Americans becoming less supportive of increased spending by European allies and Germans becoming more divided on the issue.

In 2017, a significant portion of Americans, 45%, believed that European allies should increase their defense spending. However, this sentiment has shifted notably by 2019, with half of Americans now supporting the maintenance of current spending levels [4]. ![This image shows the public opinion of Americans and Germans on national defense spending over the years 2017, 2018, and 2019.](image1) This change in perspective is particularly noticeable among Republicans, where support for increased European defense budgets has fallen by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [3].  ![This image is a line graph showing trends over three years, from 2017 to 2019, for two political affiliations: "Republican/Lean Rep" and "Democrat/Lean Dem." ](image3) In Germany, the public opinion on defense spending is divided between increasing and maintaining current levels, with about 40% supporting an increase and 41% favoring maintaining the status quo in 2019 [10]. This represents a shift from 2017, when about half of Germans were content with existing spending levels [10]. Examining partisan differences, supporters of the CDU/CSU in Germany generally favor defense spending increases, while Green Party supporters express more skepticism, with only 28% advocating for increased spending [9]. ![This image is a horizontal bar chart displaying numerical values associated with three different political parties. The parties listed are CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens. ](image5) In summary, American support for increased European defense spending has declined, particularly among Republicans, while German opinion remains divided between increasing and maintaining current levels, with partisan differences evident in their views.

![The image is a comparative bar chart that depicts the public opinion of Americans and Germans on national defense spending over the years 2017, 2018, and 2019.](image1) Opinions on defense spending differ between the U.S. and Germany. In the U.S., Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents to favor increased defense spending in Europe [3]. ![The image is a line graph showing trends over three years, from 2017 to 2019, for two political affiliations: "Republican/Lean Rep" and "Democrat/Lean Dem."](image5) However, this trend has been decreasing, with the share of Republicans who support this view falling by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019. There has also been a more modest decline in this view among Democrats [3]. In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU party generally favor increases in defense spending, while Green party supporters are more skeptical, with only 28% supporting an increase [5]. ![The image is a horizontal bar chart displaying numerical values associated with three different political parties. The parties listed are CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens. The numbers next to each party indicate specific values: CDU/CSU has 51, SPD has 41, and Greens have 28. The chart is likely used to represent poll results, seats in a parliament, or other similar data related to these political parties.](image3) SPD supporters fall somewhere in between these two viewpoints [5]. Overall, political affiliations in both countries have a notable influence on opinions regarding defense spending, with these opinions shifting slightly over time.
In conclusion, political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly influence opinions on defense spending, and these opinions have undergone some changes in recent years.

Germans' and Americans' views on the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany differ significantly.  While about half of Germans see U.S. military bases as important for their country’s national security, 45% disagree. [8] This difference is even more pronounced among younger Germans, with roughly six-in-ten Germans ages 18 to 29 believing that U.S. military bases in Germany do not contribute to German national security. [9]  ![Younger Germans (18-29) are more likely to view U.S. military bases as not important, while older Germans (65+) tend to see them as important.](image5)  In contrast, older Germans are more likely to view these bases as important. [5]  The U.S. perspective on the importance of these bases is divided along partisan lines. [10] However, it's important to note that despite this divide, support for the American military presence in Germany remains high among both Republicans and Democrats. [10]

When it comes to foreign policy partners, there are clear differences between German and American viewpoints, as well as within the U.S. based on political affiliations. [1]  ![Germans view France as their most important partner (60%), while Americans favor the UK (36%). Interestingly, Germans view the U.S. more favorably (42%) than Americans view Germany (13%).](image1)  While both Republicans and Democrats in the U.S. consider the UK their most important partner, Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel (26%) than Democrats (9%). [4]  ![Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel (26%) compared to Democrats (14%).](image4) Democrats, on the other hand, prioritize Canada and Mexico more. [4]  Despite these variations, both parties in the U.S. generally hold similar views on Germany, ranking it fifth in importance for foreign policy partnerships. [4]

In conclusion, age plays a significant role in shaping German opinions on the importance of U.S. military bases, with younger Germans expressing more skepticism. In the U.S., while support for the bases remains high overall, political affiliations influence preferences for foreign policy partners, with Republicans showing a stronger preference for Israel and Democrats placing more importance on Canada and Mexico.

Americans' views on the U.S.'s role in global engagement differ significantly along political lines.  [5]  Republicans are much more likely to prioritize domestic issues over international involvement, with about three-quarters believing the U.S. should focus on its own problems.  ![This bar chart clearly shows the division in opinions based on political affiliation, highlighting the difference between Republicans and Democrats on U.S. global engagement](image3)  This stance is consistent across various Republican subgroups, including conservatives and moderates. [5] In contrast, Democrats are more inclined towards international engagement, with over half believing the U.S. should assist other nations in addressing global challenges. [8] 
However, there's a noticeable divide within the Democratic party itself. Liberal Democrats are considerably more supportive of global engagement than their moderate and conservative counterparts. [8] The divide in viewpoints extends to education levels.  Americans with higher education levels tend to be more supportive of the U.S. taking an active role in global affairs. [10] For instance, a significant majority of postgraduates believe the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems.  This contrasts with those with lower education levels, where majorities believe the U.S. should prioritize its own issues. [10]  **Political affiliations and educational backgrounds significantly influence Americans' views on U.S. global engagement, creating a complex and divided landscape on international issues.**

Americans' views on the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, both domestically and by China, are significantly influenced by political affiliations. [3] states that a staggering 73% of Democrats/Democratic-leaning independents criticize the US response, while a similar 71% of Republicans/Republican-leaning independents commend it. This partisan gap is starkly visualized in ![This image is a chart showing political leanings towards Democratic/Lean Democrat and Republican/Lean Republican in various countries.](image2), where 71% of Republicans view the U.S. response favorably, contrasting sharply with only 27% of Democrats. This trend transcends to perceptions of other countries' responses as well. Republicans who believe in learning from other nations are more likely to view those countries' pandemic responses favorably, a pattern mirrored among Democrats. [5]

Interestingly, while political affiliation is a dominant factor in shaping views on the U.S. response, education plays a lesser role. [2] highlights that while education level correlates with criticism of the U.S. response (two-thirds of postgraduate degree holders express disapproval), the divide is less pronounced than the partisan gap. However, education has a minimal impact on opinions regarding China's handling of the pandemic. [4] asserts that majorities across all educational groups view China's response negatively, suggesting a more unified perspective on this issue. ![The image is a horizontal bar chart comparing opinions on a scale of "Only fair/poor" to "Good/excellent" across various demographic groups.](image3) further reinforces this, illustrating that while opinions on China's handling remain consistently negative across age groups and education levels, they vary significantly based on political affiliation. 

In conclusion, political affiliation is a significant factor influencing Americans' perceptions of both the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, while education plays a more prominent role in shaping views on the U.S. response.

A significant partisan gap exists in how Americans view the U.S. response to the COVID-19 pandemic [2]. While 47% of adults believe the U.S. has done a good or excellent job, this view is split starkly along partisan lines: 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents agree, compared to only 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [8]. ![This image is a bar chart showing survey results regarding people's evaluation as "Only fair/poor" or "Good/excellent." The categories include racial groups (White, Black, Hispanic), age groups, educational attainment, and political affiliations with subcategories of conservatism and liberalism. Each group is represented by two bars indicating the percentage of each evaluation. The chart provides a visual comparison across different demographics and political orientations.](image4)  This partisan divide is even more pronounced when considering China's handling of the outbreak. Although a majority in both parties believe China has not done a good job, Republicans are much more likely to hold this view [9]. In fact, eight out of ten conservative Republicans believe China mishandled the crisis [9]. This difference in perception extends to other countries' responses as well. Republicans who think the U.S. can learn from other nations are more likely to view those countries' pandemic responses favorably [1]. ![The image is a bar chart comparing different countries on the belief that the U.S. can or cannot learn from other countries. The percentages represent respondents' opinions in each country.](image1) In conclusion, political affiliations strongly influence how Americans perceive the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, with Republicans generally holding more favorable views of the U.S. response and more critical views of China's response compared to Democrats.

[1] When it comes to assessments of how well the  U.S. is dealing with the outbreak, those who  think the U.S. can learn from foreign countries  tend to evaluate its current handling of the  pandemic  less  positively. Fewer than half   $(44\%)$  of those who think the U.S. can glean  information from abroad say the country is  doing an excellent or good job handling the  outbreak, compared with  $63\%$   of those who say  the U.S. can’t learn much from overseas.  There are significant partisan differences regarding the potential for the U.S. to learn from international responses to the pandemic [6]. Democrats are more inclined to believe that the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations' experiences (60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents hold this view), while only a much smaller segment of Republicans (28%) share this sentiment [6]. This partisan gap is particularly noticeable regarding the WHO.  ![Trust in WHO based on political affiliation](image1)  A significant majority of liberal Democrats (86%) express at least a fair amount of trust in information from the WHO, a stark contrast to the 27% of conservative Republicans who say the same [10]. Similar partisan divides, though less pronounced, are observed in levels of trust towards information from the EU and the Chinese government [10].  Those who believe in the U.S.'s capacity to learn from other countries are more likely to view other nations' handling of the outbreak favorably [7]. This pattern holds true across both Democrats and Republicans - those who see value in learning from international responses tend to have a more positive assessment of how other countries are managing the pandemic [8].  In conclusion, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe that the U.S. can learn from other countries' handling of the coronavirus outbreak, and this difference in perception extends to trust in international organizations like the WHO and EU.

When asked about the future influence of the U.S., the EU, and China after the coronavirus outbreak, Americans express a range of opinions. [2] While half of Americans believe China will emerge from the current crisis with less influence, far fewer say this about the U.S. or the European Union. [2] ![The image is a bar chart comparing opinions from the U.S., the EU, and China. Each bar is divided into three categories: "More," "About the same," and "Less." The values for each region are as follows:

- U.S.: 29% for "More," 41% for "About the same," and 29% for "Less."
- EU: 19% for "More," 59% for "About the same," and 21% for "Less."
- China: 17% for "More," 31% for "About the same," and 50% for "Less."

Each category is color-coded to visually differentiate them. The chart might be showing public opinion or perceptions about a certain topic, though the specific subject isn't mentioned in the image or any accompanying text.](image3)  Clear partisan gaps emerge when examining these perspectives.  Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will be strengthened as a result of the crisis. [3] Conversely, Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to expect American influence to weaken after the outbreak. [3] This partisan divide is also evident in views about China's influence, with Republicans being more likely to predict a decline. [1] ![The image shows a bar chart displaying survey results about people’s perceptions on a particular topic. The categories are based on education level and political affiliation:

- **Education Level**:
  - Postgraduate, College grad, Some college, HS or less

- **Political Affiliation**:
  - Rep/Lean Rep (Conserv, Mod/Lib)
  - Dem/Lean Dem (Cons/Mod, Liberal)

Each category shows percentages of people who think "More," "About the same," or "Less" regarding the topic. The results are color-coded:
- Green for "More"
- Beige for "About the same"
- Blue for "Less"

For example, 29% of the total respondents believe "More," 41% believe "About the same," and 29% believe "Less." Each subgroup has different percentages reflecting their specific views.](image1)  Education level is also a factor in shaping these opinions. Americans with higher levels of education are more likely to believe that the pandemic will lead to a decline in U.S. global influence. [10]  In summary, views on the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China differ based on political affiliation, with Republicans more optimistic about U.S. influence and pessimistic about Chinese influence, while the opposite is true for Democrats. Additionally, higher education levels correlate with a belief in declining U.S. influence.

[1] shows a significant partisan gap in how the U.S.’s international influence is perceived after the coronavirus outbreak, with Republicans more optimistic than Democrats.  Democrats are internally divided, with liberals expecting a greater decline than moderates and conservatives. This aligns with the general trend observed in [7] that partisan and age divides extend to overall attitudes towards China. Older Americans and Republicans are more likely to hold negative views. ![The image shows a bar chart about people’s perceptions on U.S. international influence after the coronavirus outbreak, categorized by education level and political affiliation.](image1) Interestingly, [9] highlights that Americans with higher education levels are more likely to believe that the U.S.’s global influence will decline.  This suggests a nuanced perspective within the Democratic party, potentially driven by factors beyond just political affiliation.  On the other hand, [3] reveals a more pessimistic outlook regarding China's global influence, with half of Americans believing it will decline. This sentiment is further corroborated by [10], which states that 50% of Americans predict China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic. This negative perception is rooted in the rising unfavorable opinion of China, reaching 66% as per a March Pew Research Center survey [10].  ![The image compares the predicted influence of the U.S., EU, and China in world affairs after the coronavirus outbreak, showing public opinion or perceptions about a certain topic.](image2) provides a comparative view of these predictions, showing a less pronounced but still noticeable trend of declining influence for both the US and China, while the EU remains relatively unaffected. The partisan divide on China is evident in [4], with a significantly higher proportion of Republicans (60%) than Democrats (40%) expecting a decline in China’s influence. This divide is further emphasized by age, with older Americans (65+) being more likely to foresee a decline compared to those under 30 [4]. ![The image is a bar chart comparing opinions from different political groups on the influence of China in world affairs after the coronavirus outbreak, categorized into "More," "About the same," and "Less".](image4) illustrates these demographic divides, showcasing how perceptions of China's future global standing vary across age, race, and political affiliations.  In conclusion, while predictions about both the U.S. and China's global influence after the outbreak show a downward trend, there's a clear distinction in the perceptions of these declines based on political affiliation and age, particularly towards China.

A March Pew Research Center survey found that  $66\%$ of  Americans expressed an unfavorable opinion of China [9].  Nearly two-thirds of Americans say China has not done a good job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak, including  $37\%$  who say the country has done a poor job [3]. ![This image is a bar chart comparing perceptions of performance across various categories for seven entities: South Korea, Germany, UK, U.S., WHO, Italy, and China. Each entity is evaluated on a scale ranging from "Poor" to "Excellent."

- **South Korea**: Poor (7%), Only fair (22%), Good (41%), Excellent (25%)
- **Germany**: Poor (4%), Only fair (25%), Good (51%), Excellent (15%)
- **UK**: Poor (9%), Only fair (38%), Good (44%), Excellent (5%)
- **U.S.**: Poor (21%), Only fair (31%), Good (37%), Excellent (10%)
- **WHO**: Poor (24%), Only fair (27%), Good (37%), Excellent (9%)
- **Italy**: Poor (27%), Only fair (36%), Good (28%), Excellent (6%)
- **China**: Poor (37%), Only fair (26%), Good (26%), Excellent (7%)

The chart shows different levels of approval or satisfaction with each entity's performance.](image5) Many believe that this will impact China's global stature, with  $50\%$  saying China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic [9]. ![This image is a bar chart showing levels of influence. 

- "Less influence" is represented by the longest bar, with a value of 50.
- "About the same influence" has a shorter bar with a value of 31.
- "More influence" has the shortest bar with a value of 17.](image3)  However, there are significant partisan differences in these attitudes, with Republicans expressing significantly more negative attitudes towards China [4].  Roughly six-in-ten Republicans believe China’s international clout will diminish as a result of the coronavirus outbreak, while just  $40\%$  of Democrats say the same [5]. Republicans are much more likely than Democrats to say that China has not done a good job dealing with the outbreak [7]. Americans perceive China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively and believe it will lead to diminished global influence for China, though there is a partisan divide with Republicans holding more negative views than Democrats.

[5] About six-in-ten Republicans   $(62\%)$   now think the U.S. does  too much in helping address global challenges, while just   $_{26\%}$   of Democrats share this  view. In Pew Research Center  telephone surveys dating back  to 2013, the partisan gap in  these views was far more  modest.  Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will be strengthened as a result of the crisis [10],  while Democrats are about  four times more likely than Republicans to  expect American influence to  weaken  after the outbreak [10]. ![Democrats are more likely to believe that the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs after the coronavirus outbreak than Republicans](image1) The difference in partisan views was less significant in 2013 compared to 2020, with Republicans being more likely to believe that the U.S. is doing too much to help address global challenges and that the U.S.’s international influence will be strengthened after the coronavirus outbreak, while Democrats are more likely to believe that the U.S. should do more and that its influence will weaken.

[8] However, there are significant partisan differences over how much the U.S. can learn from the international response. While  $60\%$  of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents say the U.S. can learn a great deal, just  $_{2}8\%$  of Republicans and Republican leaners share that view.   [4] Even though the belief that the U.S. can learn at least a fair amount from the rest of the world is widely shared across the political spectrum, those on the left are much more likely to think the country can learn   $a$    great deal from other nations:  $67\%$  of liberal Democrats hold this view, compared with only  $25\%$  of conservative Republicans. ![The chart highlights differences in perceptions between political groups regarding these issues.](image5)  This partisan divide extends to broader questions of foreign policy and America's role in global affairs.  [6] There are sharp partisan and ideological differences on other questions about foreign policy and international affairs included in the survey. While  $81\%$  of liberal Democrats think the U.S. has done an only fair or poor job of dealing with the coronavirus outbreak, just  $_{22\%}$  of conservative Republicans say the same. Liberal Democrats stand apart for their bleak assessment of how the pandemic will affect America’s standing on the global stage:  $56\%$  believe the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs, 20 percentage points higher than the share of moderate and conservative Democrats who say this (just  $15\%$  of moderate and liberal Republicans and  $8\%$  of conservative Republicans say the U.S. will have less influence). Democrats are significantly more likely than Republicans to believe that the U.S. can learn from other countries in addressing the pandemic and that the U.S. has a responsibility to help other nations, and they are more pessimistic about the impact of the pandemic on America's global standing.

More than eight-in-ten  Americans say the U.S. can  learn either a great deal or a  fair amount from other  countries about ways to slow  the spread of the coronavirus [10], but when it comes to whether the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, Americans are more divided.  $60\%$ of Americans believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems and let other countries deal with their own problems as best they can [2]. ![The chart shows the percentage of people who think the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems is lower than the percentage of people who think the U.S. should deal with its own problems](image1) This view is particularly strong among Republicans, with about three-quarters taking this stance [6]. Democrats are more divided, with $46\%$ supporting this approach and a slightly higher $54\%$ believing the U.S. should help other countries [4]. 

Interestingly, views on helping other countries also differ by education level. Individuals with higher levels of education are more likely to support helping other nations.  For example, six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should offer assistance [9].  In contrast, a clear majority of those with some college experience or a high school diploma or less believe the U.S. should prioritize its own problems [9]. ![The chart shows the percentage of people who think the U.S. should help other countries increases as the level of education increases](image2)

In conclusion, Republicans and those with lower levels of education are more likely to prioritize the U.S. dealing with its own problems, while Democrats and those with higher education are more likely to support helping other countries.

A 2018 Pew Research Center survey found that a majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to solve world problems, while only 8% think it does too little, and 29% believe it does the right amount [3]. In contrast, a plurality of Democrats (48%) think the U.S. does too little, while 26% each say it does the right amount or too much [3]. This partisan divide has become more pronounced over time, as noted in telephone surveys from previous years [6]. ![The graph shows the change in opinions about the U.S.'s role in solving world problems over time.](image3) Republicans, particularly conservative Republicans, overwhelmingly believe that the U.S. should focus on its own issues rather than helping other countries solve theirs [8]. On the other hand, more than half of Democrats believe that the U.S. should assist other countries with their problems [7]. Notably, there is a significant divide among Democrats based on ideology, with liberal Democrats being more likely to support helping other countries (64%) compared to conservative and moderate Democrats (44%) [7]. ![The image depicts varying views on the U.S. handling its own problems versus assisting others, broken down by demographics and political affiliations.](image2) In conclusion, Republicans are more likely to believe that the U.S. is overly involved in global affairs, while Democrats generally believe that the U.S. should do more to help other nations. This partisan gap has widened over the years.

Republicans are more inclined than Democrats to prioritize domestic issues over global engagement. [1]  A 62% majority of Republicans believe the U.S. is overly involved in addressing global challenges, contrasting sharply with 26% of Democrats who share this sentiment. [1] This partisan divide extends to opinions on the U.S.'s role in the world, with 60% advocating for the U.S. to focus on its own problems and let other countries manage their own affairs. [8] Conversely, Democrats are more likely to support international engagement, with 46% believing the U.S. should help other countries address their problems. [5]

Education level also influences perspectives on global engagement. Individuals with higher levels of education tend to be more supportive of the U.S. taking an active role in global affairs. [6] For instance, 60% of those with postgraduate degrees believe the U.S. should assist other countries. [6]  ![The graph shows people with postgraduate degrees are more likely to help other countries solve problems.](image1)  In contrast, those with less education are more likely to prioritize domestic issues. [6]

Americans express a significant level of concern regarding various issues related to China. For instance,  a combined 91% consider cyberattacks from China a serious problem, with 65% deeming it "very serious." [4] ![The image is a bar chart showing survey results on various perceived serious issues related to China.](image4) Similarly, 86% express concern about China's growing military power. [8] This apprehension towards China's actions contrasts with Americans' confidence in Biden's ability to handle China, which is lower than their confidence in his approach to other foreign policy issues. [1]  ![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of people who believe in varying degrees of effectiveness (from "Not at all" to "Very") on different foreign policy and global issues.](image1) While 53% of Americans believe Biden can effectively deal with China, this is the lowest among six tested foreign policy areas.  [2] Americans are more confident in his ability to improve relations with allies (67%) or address terrorism (60%). [2] This suggests a disconnect between the perceived seriousness of China-related issues and the confidence in Biden's ability to address them.  Americans are more likely to view issues like protecting American jobs (85%) and combating terrorism (81%) as higher priorities than limiting China's power and influence (63%). [2]  ![The image displays a comparison of two lists indicating different priorities or concerns. ](image2) This difference in prioritization could explain the lower confidence in Biden's approach to China.  In conclusion, while Americans express significant concern about China-related issues, their confidence in Biden's capacity to handle these issues effectively remains relatively low.

Americans have less faith in Biden to deal with China than on other foreign policy issues [9].  ![This bar chart compares the perceived effectiveness of Biden's policies on different issues, with "Dealing effectively with China" having the lowest combined "Somewhat" and "Very" rating.](image5) Around half of Americans have confidence Biden will be able  to deal effectively with China $(53\%)$ [2]. However, this confidence level varies across different demographics.  For instance, women $(59\%)$ are more confident than men $(48\%)$ in Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China [10]. Similarly, Black $(82\%)$ and Hispanic adults $(70\%)$ express more confidence than White adults $(43\%)$ [10]. ![The image shows a bar graph illustrating the confidence levels in a particular matter, potentially leadership or institutional trust, across different demographic groups.](image2)  When considering political affiliations, only $19\%$ of Republicans and Republican leaners have confidence in Biden on China, compared to $83\%$ of Democrats and Democrat leaners [3]. ![The chart illustrates the percentage of individuals, categorized by political affiliation (Democrats/Lean Democrat and Republicans/Lean Republican), who perceive specific countries as threats.](image4)  Americans express substantial concern over several specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship [5].  ![This chart presents data on the perceived seriousness of various China-related issues, with cyberattacks, China's military power, trade deficit, and job losses standing out as major concerns.](image3) These concerns include cyberattacks from China, China’s growing military power, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, and China’s policies on human rights [5]. While "limiting the power and influence of China" is a priority for Americans, it ranks lower than issues like protecting American jobs, counterterrorism, and maintaining military superiority. ![The image shows a side-by-side comparison of two lists that highlight different priorities or concerns.](image1) The level of confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China varies across demographic groups, with women, Black and Hispanic adults, and Democrats expressing higher levels of confidence, while concerns about China primarily revolve around cybersecurity, military power, economic competition, and human rights.

Americans have many specific concerns when it comes to China [9].  These concerns, including cyberattacks, job losses, and China's growing technological power, are considered major problems by a significant portion of the population, and this sentiment has only grown over the past year [9]. ![This bar chart shows the percentage of people who consider specific issues related to China as "very serious" or "somewhat serious".](image4) For instance, half of Americans now view China's human rights policy as a very serious problem for the U.S., marking a 7 percentage point increase from the previous year [9]. This sentiment aligns with a broader view that nine-in-ten Americans hold – that China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [9]. Despite these concerns, confidence in then-President Biden's ability to deal with China varied significantly across different demographics and political affiliations [6].  ![This image shows a bar graph comparing different demographic groups' confidence levels in an unspecified matter.](image3) While 83% of Democrats and those leaning towards the Democratic Party expressed confidence in Biden's approach to China, only 19% of Republicans and Republican leaners shared this sentiment [8]. This partisan divide is particularly stark, highlighting the deep political polarization surrounding U.S.-China relations. In conclusion, while Americans express serious concerns about a range of issues related to China, confidence in the president's ability to address these issues is sharply divided along partisan lines.

Americans express substantial concern when  asked about specific issues in the U.S.- China relationship. About three-quarters or  more say that each issue is at least somewhat  serious [10].  ![{The image is a bar chart showing survey results on various perceived serious issues related to China.}](image2) Cyber attacks from China evoke the most  concern: Roughly two-thirds consider digital  attacks to be a very serious problem [7]. The share seeing  China’s growing military power as a very  serious problem is largely unchanged from the prior year [8].  Concern about various China-related issues generally increased more among  Republicans than among Democrats [9]. ![{The image is a series of line graphs that depict the percentage of people who consider certain issues related to China as a very serious problem for the U.S., split by political affiliation}](image3) Few Republicans have confidence in  Biden to deal effectively with China [2]. ![{The image appears to be a bar graph showing levels of confidence among different demographic groups}](image1)  Partisan differences are particularly large: 83%  of Democrats and those who lean toward  the Democratic Party have confidence in Biden  on China, compared to only 19% of Republicans and those who lean Republican [3].  Confidence levels in Biden's ability to deal with China vary greatly by political affiliation, with Democrats expressing significantly higher confidence than Republicans, and Americans are most concerned about cyberattacks, China's growing military power, and the loss of U.S. jobs to China.

Americans overwhelmingly believe that the Chinese government does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [6]. In fact, nine out of ten Americans hold this view, a perspective that transcends age, education, and political affiliations [6]. ![The image shows two bar graphs, one about perceptions of China respecting personal freedoms and the other about U.S. priorities in its relations with China.](image1) This sentiment is particularly relevant when considering how Americans perceive China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. While a majority of Americans believe China did a bad job dealing with the outbreak [7], there is a stark contrast in the level of agreement on these two issues [7, 6]. This difference suggests that while Americans are critical of China's pandemic response, their concern about China's human rights record is far more unified and profound. When it comes to U.S. priorities in its relationship with China, a significant majority of Americans (70%) believe that the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights, even if it could potentially harm economic relations. ![The image shows two bar graphs, one about perceptions of China respecting personal freedoms and the other about U.S. priorities in its relations with China.](image1)  This stance underscores the importance Americans place on human rights in the U.S.-China relationship. In conclusion, Americans overwhelmingly perceive China's human rights record negatively and prioritize promoting human rights in U.S.-China relations, even if it may have economic implications.

Republican support for a tougher approach to China, including on human rights, likely stems from a combination of economic concerns and a more adversarial view of China's global role, as exemplified by the previous administration's policies [2]. Democrats, on the other hand, while still supportive of human rights promotion, are more inclined towards diplomacy and building stronger ties with China, potentially reflecting a belief in the importance of engagement for addressing global challenges [9].

In conclusion, Republicans and Democrats prioritize human rights over economic ties with China, however, they differ in their motivations and proposed approaches to U.S. - China relations.

A significant majority of Americans,  $70\%$ , believe that the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights in China, even if it could negatively impact economic relations [7]. This sentiment is shared by both Democrats and Republicans, with about seven in ten members of each party supporting this stance [10].  ![This chart shows the percentage of respondents, grouped by political affiliation, who believe the US should prioritize promoting human rights in China even if it harms economic relations.](image1) Notably, conservative Republicans show a stronger preference (77%) for prioritizing human rights over economic interests compared to their moderate/liberal counterparts (66%) within the Republican Party.  Interestingly, this pattern is reversed among Democrats, with liberal Democrats being more likely (76%) to emphasize human rights over economic considerations compared to their conservative/moderate peers (64%). This suggests that while both parties generally agree on the importance of human rights, the intensity of this belief and its implications for economic policy differ within each party's ideological spectrum.

However, when it comes to economic and trade policies, there is a clear partisan divide. Republicans, particularly conservative Republicans, are more inclined towards taking a tougher stance on China [6]. In fact, 81% of conservative Republicans believe the U.S. should prioritize getting tougher on China [5]. This stance aligns with the general sentiment among Americans, with a majority (53%) favoring a tougher approach over building a stronger economic relationship [9]. ![This chart shows the percentage of respondents, grouped by demographic and political affiliation, who support either getting tougher with China or building a stronger relationship.](image5) On the other hand, Democrats are more likely to favor focusing on building stronger ties with China [6]. This difference in opinion likely stems from varying perspectives on the effectiveness of tariffs and the potential economic repercussions of a confrontational approach. 

In conclusion, while both Democrats and Republicans broadly agree on prioritizing human rights over economic interests in US-China relations, they diverge significantly on trade policies, with Republicans favoring a tougher stance and Democrats preferring a less confrontational approach.

Americans' views on the impact of trade policies with China and their preferred approach to U.S.-China relations vary significantly along partisan lines [1, 4].  Republicans, particularly conservative Republicans, are more likely to believe that increased tariffs on Chinese products were beneficial for the U.S. ![This image is a bar chart showing the perspectives of different political groups on whether they believe something is "Bad for the U.S.," has "No real effect," or is "Good for the U.S."](image5)  This aligns with their preference for a tougher stance on China, with 72% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents supporting this approach [1]. Democrats, on the other hand, predominantly view the tariffs as detrimental to the U.S. [2] and are more inclined towards building a stronger relationship with China. This partisan divide is evident in the fact that while a majority of Democrats favor building stronger ties, a significant majority of Republicans advocate for a tougher stance ![The image is a bar chart showing percentages divided between two categories for different political groups. It seems to be representing some kind of opinion or demographic distribution. Each group has two bars with corresponding percentages, one in blue and one in green, which together add up to 100%.](image1). ](image2) This suggests a complex perspective where even those who approve of tougher economic measures recognize the existing strain in the bilateral economic relationship. In conclusion, Republicans are more likely to support a tougher stance on China and view tariffs favorably, while Democrats generally hold the opposite view, preferring stronger relations and seeing tariffs as harmful.

Republicans tend to view the impacts of tariffs more favorably than Democrats [1]. About half of Republicans believe that increased tariffs on Chinese and other foreign products have benefited the U.S., a sentiment particularly prevalent among conservative Republicans [10]. Conversely, Democrats generally perceive these tariffs as detrimental to the U.S. economy [10]. ![The chart depicts the political divide in perceiving the impacts of tariffs on the U.S., with Republicans generally viewing them more favorably than Democrats.](image3)  This partisan gap is also evident in opinions regarding international students, especially those from China [2, 8]. While a strong majority of Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents (92%) view international students as beneficial to U.S. universities, only 67% of Republicans and Republican-leaners share this perspective [2]. ![The chart illustrates the public's overall positive view of international students, with notable differences based on political affiliation, particularly regarding Chinese students.](image1) This difference in opinion is further highlighted by the fact that 69% of Republicans support limiting Chinese students studying in the U.S., compared to only 42% of Democrats [8]. ![The chart displays varying levels of support for limiting Chinese students in the U.S., with Republicans showing a higher level of support compared to Democrats.](image5) In conclusion, Republicans and Democrats hold contrasting views on the impacts of tariffs and the presence of international students, particularly Chinese students, in the U.S.

[6] While a majority of Americans (55%) support limiting Chinese students studying in the U.S., there is a significant divide in opinions across age groups and political affiliations.  Older Americans are more likely to support limitations on Chinese students. [3] For instance, nearly 70% of Americans aged 50 and older favor limiting Chinese students. This contrasts sharply with the younger generation, where nearly two-thirds of those aged 18 to 29 oppose the idea. [10] This age-based disparity in opinion towards Chinese students aligns with the differing levels of confidence in the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, across age groups. Older Americans are more likely to have no confidence in Xi, with 53% of those aged 65 and older expressing this sentiment, compared to only 35% of those aged 18 to 29. ![The image is a bar chart showing levels of confidence in a certain topic, divided by different demographic groups.](image1) The data suggests a potential correlation between distrust in the Chinese leadership and support for limiting Chinese students among older Americans.  Furthermore, Republicans are more likely than Democrats to support limiting the number of Chinese students in U.S. universities. [3] This partisan divide is also evident in the levels of confidence in Xi Jinping, with Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents showing slightly more confidence in him compared to Republicans. [5] ![The image is a chart displaying survey results on opinions toward an unspecified topic, categorized by various demographics in the U.S.](image4)  In conclusion, older Americans and Republicans are more likely to support limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities, and this aligns with their lower levels of confidence in the Chinese leadership.

Americans express substantial concern over eight specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship [9].  These concerns are cyberattacks originating from China, the loss of domestic jobs to China, the growing military power of China, and China's policies on human rights [9]. ![The image shows the percentage change from 2020 to 2021 in concerns about China, including a 7% increase in concerns about cyberattacks and human rights policies.](image1)  Furthermore, there is a growing sense that China's human rights policy, its technological advancements, and cyberattacks pose significant problems, as indicated by a recent surge in concern over the past year [10]. ![This image shows a bar chart comparing the percentage of people with and without confidence in the government's ability to handle various global issues.
